resources.string: This open area at the edge of Old Town is a place of national symbolism and civic pride.
Tallinn\'s grandest 19th-century church sets itself apart with its twin steeples, immense size and neo-Roman style.
The bright yellow, neo-Gothic church that dominates Freedom Square is a true survivor among the city\'s churches.
This massive, 38m-high cannon tower houses an extensive museum of the town\'s fortifications, weapons and medieval-era life.
This grand, baroque palace built for Peter the Great in 1718 now houses the Art Museum of Estonia\'s foreign collection.
This vast park surrounding Kadriorg Palace is without a doubt the best place in town for relaxed strolling.
By far the nation\'s largest and most cutting-edge art museum.
This striking monument on Kadriorg\’s shore is a memorial to those lost when armoured ship Russalka sank in 1893.
The park around Glehn\'s Castle in the Nõmme suburb is popular for walking, star gazing and winter skiing.
Built by Nikolai von Glehn in 1886 and set a forested park, this castle provides a perfect escape from city centre bustle.
Find this family cemetery on the former estate of Nikolai von Glehn.
Nõmme Market is a colourful market bulging with domestic products.
Nothing says power like the impressive, Gothic Town Hall that dominates medieval Tallinn\'s main square.
Easily the most picturesque of Old Town\'s lanes, this half-hidden walkway runs behind what used to be St. Catherine\'s Church.
Perched on a limestone cliff and towering over the rest of the city, Toompea Castle has always been the seat of power in Estonia.
This spectacular, onion-domed structure perched atop Toompea Hill is Estonia\'s main Russian Orthodox cathedral.
